Player Unknown Battleground, or better known as wait 7 minute to land and get into a game and die within a minute. Rinse and repeat. 

In 2022, in order to play a game,  you need to wait 5 minute to get into a single player game with bots. 1 minute, count down for the game to start, long introduction scene for a plane, which at the earliest, takes 1 minute to land. All in all, Player Unknown Battleground, isn't really a battle ground. It's a bunch of people wasting their life away waiting for a game just to start. 

Most of the time, you wait four minute. One minute for the game to start and one minute to get on the actual ground. It states, estimated waiting time is 1:10 seconds for example. This is varied, the actual waiting time can increase. The current average experienced for me, is five minute and fifty seconds. 

You would get into a map to WAIT for the game to get enough players AND THEN start a minute count down, and it will still take you another MINUTE to get onto the battleground. 

Game is fun when you are not waiting. In my honest opinion, this game is literally a waiting game. If you have nothing to do for twenty five minute, you've be looking at your screen and see little to no actions at times and come out winning. The reward for winning is minuscule and the amount of fun you may have is subjective. 

There are different methods of winning of course, but I often find myself waiting for the circle to close, to find any opponents. I often find sea servers people camped, literally outside of the house, building etc. Incredibly frustrating after waiting average of four minute.

There are elements of fun, but there are also quite a number of hackers to make sure you don't have too much fun. 

The Aeroplane scene and landing takes, at the earliest, 56 seconds by the time you get onto land. I cannot stop mentioning, how much you stare at your screen before you have get any action. 

May be I don't have as much time as I would as a teenager and time is worth more to me. Nothing is worse than coming onto a game on a Saturday to wait average four minute to get onto the battleground. I do not want to spend four minute staring at my screen for copious amount of time doing quite literally nothing. 

In conclusion, the idea of winning seems to be greater than actually winning. It provides an illusion that through winning, it would be a momentous point where the game provides a greater reward, but in reality, you have just wasted thirty minute of your Saturday squinting at the dots that might be people. I have found lots of plants in the distance that looks like players. To my massive disappointment, it was just another plant.

PUBG is the original battle royale success. Yes, it's a janky shooter adapted from a mod, and yes the cosmetics are more often than not utter garbage. However, no battle royale on the market right now really emulates the formula PUBG got so right in 2017: a semi-hardcore, no frills, classsic battle royale experience. The weapon recoil is meaty, and the TTK can be super fast if you're caught out of position. The almost-bloated set of controls it borrows from ARMA add to the feeling and atmosphere of PUBG. 

Gameplay-wise, PUBG's high-skill movement and recoil create a layer of complexity over the simple BR game mode. After hundreds of hours I am still learning new tech and ways to utilize equipment and the environment. Driving is also incredibly fun; car handling feels appropriate to each vehicle, and the game gives plenty incentive and opportunity to use them. On occasion however, inexplicable sharp bumps in the terrain will have you scratching your head.

As for flaws, my biggest gripe with PUBG is the cosmetics and monetization. This game follows the old lootbox model, one of the most unsatisfying ways to earn cosmetics and a great way to enable gambling addiction. On top of that, the vast majority of the cosmetics sold in game are either terrible or hyper-tailored to PUBG's Korean market, with KPOP marketing deals and accompanying attire. Fortunately, this side of the game can be ignored, and you can find some of the older skins on the steam marketplace for pennies. The one area in PUBG's cosmetics I will praise is the esports integration.

Getting into PUBG as a newcomer may be hard, but if you feel the style of PUBG's slower pace and semi-hardcore combat is for you, try it out and see if the formula sucks you in.

Back in the day, when this game first came out, it was great. Yeah, it was only one map, and yeah, it was a little rough, but it was still fun. The game was going somewhere and looked like it was going to be a really great game...and at one point, it was. However, things started going down hill fast. At one point, getting a sniper rifle or a designated marksmen rifle was rare, and now, with just a few minutes of looting, almost everyone has one. So, instead of a "battle royal," it's a total camp fest. Things also don't seem to sync correctly. In other battle royal and fps games, when you shoot at your target, you're either hitting it because you're aiming at it, or you're missing it because you're not...with this game, I've unloaded a full-auto blast at almost point blank, aiming down the barrel at my target, and I've only hit them twice? Then they turn around, seemingly only hit me once and I'm dead? Then you watch the death cam, and you see a bunch of blood coming from your target, meaning you've hit it more than twice, but apparently, you've only done like 12 damage...point blank, with a 7.62 round?

Let's not even talk about what happened to the game once they made it free to play. First, the "reward" for the people that bought the game before it was made free was a joke and a spit in the face of it's loyal players. Next, it opened the door for cheaters. Now, I'll admit that cheaters have always been a problem, but not nearly as bad as it is now. What's to stop people from cheating on a free game? The matchmaking in this game is also a joke. I'd rather sit and wait to get into a match knowing that I'm playing against people at or at least near my level...however, instead, you're either thrown into a bot filled world that are so easy to kill that you could probably walk up to them and slap them to death, or you're thrown into a world with a bunch of lvl 500s that have probably played this game so much that they're unaware of the world around them. I've won a few matches, and I've lost a few matches, and while I'll admit, I don't like to lose, I'd at least feel better about losing if it somewhat seemed fair. The fact that almost every death feels like you got cheated is enough to make me consider never playing this game again.

I truly enjoy this difficult game that is known as PubG. This game does take some time to get used to. But that is why this is game is so fun. It's a grind. It's not like Apex or CoD. This game actually requires skill as there's no aim assist. I have almost 600 hours on the game now and I can confidently say this game does require patience and grinding. You will get better at it with time and effort. This is not an easy game by any means. If you want a game that rewards you for playing on the sticks with aim assist, go play apex or cod. Otherwise, take the Ls as they come and just get better. P.S. TDM and casual modes for new players are going to be your best friend. I was playing TDM until I reached level 300. That's when I felt confident enough to take my skills to the BR mode. This game is very fun. Would love to see a revive system though. I think that's all this game really needs.

Let's be real here, in my personal point of view, I definitely have always preferred PUBG over Fortnite and alot of that comes down to the realism and survival instincts when it comes to gameplay wise, on the other hand Fortnite is nothing but a cartoon like shooter that's all about building those damn structures. PUBG like I said it usually focuses more on realistic gameplay that has to do with seeing who the last person standing will win while looting for items to use in combat while trying to keep yourself inside the ring without dying from like 80 to 100 different people. 

If you've ever watched the Hunger Games movie or another one that came out of Japan from the early 2000's called "Battle Royale" then basically that's what PUBG is. Sure it does have it's own problems with the game here and there like the cheating part and honestly I totally agree, I do think the cheaters do need some kind of punishment if they're caught otherwise. Although there was a time when I first started playing this game earlier this year when I was in practice mode, I had a bot literally kill me without aiming down their sights which that I wasn't mad about or anything but, I thought it was very weird to me at first and luckily I still have a recording to prove all of this.  

So far from my experience though, I haven't really dealt with any cheaters or hackers as much as other people have given my over 20 hours total playtime of this game like a casual gamer like everybody else in the crowd. 

Also I was able to make a few friends with others on PUBG through the use of Discord and while sure yeah we were pretty horrible in a few matches from time to time, it was still pretty fun getting those kills and what not. 

All I can say is that I enjoy PUBG for what it was going for and while I haven't been able to get a winner winner chicken dinner in the game I still enjoy it for what it is. If you're someone who's got tired of playing Fortnite or you're someone like me who is bad at Fortnite, then please give PUBG a go, because I promise you that you will not regret it especially given that the game has been free to play for about a couple months now at the time of me writing this. 

Also, if you're someone who has 4 GB of RAM or less, then I don't think you'll be able to run this game, I ran this game on my new gaming computer around the same time this game went free to play back in January and oh boy it looked amazing on my new computer. Of course given that I have 16 GB of RAM, I'm not sure what it could've looked like on my old computer with 8 GB of RAM but, I'm pretty sure it would've looked a lot worse since my GB of RAM on that old computer was horrible for the time plus I still would've had to pay 30 dollars to get PUBG but luckily I don't have to worry about all that anymore. 

I think that's about all I have to say, if you have any questions on what I've mentioned or said, then please feel free to reply to my review and one last thing before I go, if I had to give a rating for PUBG on PC, I would give it an 8 out of 10. Alright that's my review bye!

I am a 37 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

My opinion is very biased since I'm not into realistic or tactical shooters and prefer more "arcade-like" unrealistic shooters, but for me, the game felt really unpolished, really slow-paced, I hated the gun recoil (I don't care if it's realistic and you just have to "git gud". It's not fun and that's what matters the most in videogames). It takes forever to walk from one place to another in a large map since there are so few vehicles around, the game's intentory management is horrible (there's no color coding on attachments and you just have to memorize everything and you can't just glimpse on items and immediately know what goes where etc. unlike in Apex Legends). Fortnite also has a much simpler UI that (just like Apex) has color coding on items so you can immediately see what item is better and there's no tedious management involved.

My opinion is biased but if you're also a person who's enjoyed Quakes, Unreal Tournaments etc. in your childhood, PUBG just doesn't scratch that itch and I'd recommend something like Fortnite and Apex Legends way more than this. The tempo is greater, there's more fun to be had and they just seem more polished overall.

The game is what i want from one BR game. It has the aspects of survival and FPS with realistic elements. Coming from Apex and Warzone (my previous BR's that i've played) the game is much more hard and punishing, but for me this is not a negative, since i'm competitive player and i like to be engaged. Gun play is good, it takes a skill to shoot the weapons (not like in WZ that there is not much recoil at all or aim assist), there is no corny aspects that make u rage as in WZ ( Dead silence, Ghost perk, Heartbeat sensor, UAV's) or the  ability spam and armor from Apex. I know theese games are all different from eachother , but they are all BR's and for me (in my eyes) PUBG is proper BR game , how one BR should be. Now by no means that does not mean the game is perfect. It has its flaws, but overall i like it and i will keep playn for sure. (Where Apex and WZ lost me and i never gonna go back to them). Plus the game now is FREE. What more u want? If someone of u that never played this game and wonder...i recommend it.. give it a try.

Second point, and most noticeable, it has ton of innuendo, sexualised clothing for women, all of them almost, I tried, being a disciple of Christ, not to pay attention to them but even the Battle Pass has them, strip-club clothing, and some clothes even show exposed underwear, parents beware this game is although innocent in action-wise provocative content, it for sure fails and is too sexualised in terms of women's poses in stores/item-shops and clothing itself is over exposed and over emphasised. Furthermore, the ease of gender switching your character is as if to add insult to the wound as it almost encourages people to change clothing, giving players a temptation of trying on clothes for the other gender, I am speaking from experience. the game even allowing to strip them to their underwear, at least not fully naked thank goodness.

I just played this game for the first time in probably 4+ years. 122 of my 123 hours of playtime were from the first year the game dropped.

Downloaded and installed the game today, hopped in, and what do I get? 

A notification telling me that if I want to play all the other modes (arcade, normal, hardcore, ETC.) I have to take a basic training course and then play 10 matches against AI. 

So I after it taking THREE ATTEMPTS to get through the basic AI (I kept losing connection to the servers for some fucking reason, why the fuck does your tutorial need to be connected to the servers?!) I played an AI match. 

And after realizing that it took me nearly 30 minutes to complete just one match alone and that I needed to do that 9 more times, I decided that PUBG is scuffed and I uninstalled. 

I'm going back to Apex or Warzone or even Fortnite Zero Build now.

UPDATE: Apparently there are challenges you can do, and if you beat the challenges, you can get access to the real multiplayer sooner than completing he AI matches. That or if you have friends with the true multiplayer unlocked, you can party with them and play against real people.

You insist on imposing something stupid like 'reputation level' on players and demoralize them. The players naturally don't want to wait too long because the server doesn't fill up quickly or they don't want to watch when the team plays and die, they want to start a new round, so you can't punish the players, this is unfair!.
Also, it would be better if you bring us the option to choose a map.'Of course, if you can stop making items for the store ;)'

I bought this back in the day, played for awhile before the "Seasons" were really a thing and occasionally come back. Dropped it as they pushed for it to become an "esports" franchise - servers were bad, lag was bad, vehicles handled like cows with rockets on rollerskates and rather than addressing issues they just started offering cosmetics. Yuck. 

Noticed it went F2P recently, so I gave it a reinstall.

It's been... interesting. Some things feel much smoother, hit detection feels a little better - but the continuous streamlining and removal of options is frustrating. The bots are still garbage and they're populating servers with them now. Cheating is *still* rampant. Like literally 4/5 matches I've been domed by someone who has been following me through terrain and then snaps to my head. Drop rates are insane (who needs care packages?) Being forced to play AI missions after clocking so many hours seems like a slap in the face. Krafton (nee Bluehole) doesn't care, they made their money and are swallowing up dev studios left and right. 

Eh, for the price of free give it a whirl if you've got the space but it's still a buggy mess. Kinda fun to play with friends until you hit that match with some script kiddie who's just lazering everyones heads from a billion miles away.

The Hog Rider is a fast ground troop with medium hit points, low damage, and the ability to jump over enemy Walls. He is unlocked at level 2 Dark Barracks.
The Hog Rider (person) is a bare-chested dark-skinned man holding a hammer. He has a Mohawk, wears a brown leather loincloth, a red belt, and a pair of leather sandals, as well as two large golden wristbands and a gold earring.
His ride is a large hog, about half his height. It has a brown leather bridle looped around its tusks, which in turn is held by the Hog Rider.
Hog Riders prioritize defensive structures above all other targets, and will bypass all other types of enemy buildings and troops while any defenses remain on the battlefield. This is true even if they are under attack by enemy Clan Castle troops, heroes or Skeleton Trap skeletons. Note that like all troops that prioritize defenses, Hog Riders do not consider the Clan Castle to be a defense regardless of whether or not it contains enemy troops, but do consider the defending Grand Warden and the activated Town Hall weapon (if any) to be defensive buildings.
Once all defenses are destroyed, Hog Riders become like any other troop with no preferred target; they will attack the nearest building to them regardless of type, and will turn and attack enemy units if they become aware of any nearby.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

[h1]When the Koreans (KRAFTON) bought this game back from The Chinese (Tencent 操你妈 Valorante 习近平 June 5, 1989), I had my doubts. I just couldn't believe they could save the dumpster fire it has become.[/h1]

Some back story: despite the meteoric rise of the Battle Royal era at first, and all the big streamers streaming PUBG, the game gradually died out due to lack of attention by then new owners, Tencent. With game-ruining bugs and servers filled to the brim with bots, the fate of the game seemed to be sealed.

All changed when the original developers, KRAFTON, bought the rights back to the game. The old developers clearly care a lot about their baby, and it shows by the amount of love and attention they give to it. 
You can expect:
[list]
    [*]Constant bug fixes 
    [*]Constant addition of new content such as new weapons, gear, maps, mods and more.
    [*]Fortnite-level of collabs (relatively, consider this to be their eastern counterparts), such as BLACKPINK and NieR:Automata. 
[/list]

Granted, PUBG mobile does get a lot more weapons, content and collabs added to it than the PC version (They literally got an Among Us collab lmao), but the trend is clear: 

[b]The F2P transition brought the game back to life, and the developers seem vigor to make it stay like that for as much as possible.[/b]

If you are looking for a challenging Battle Royal shooter with a high skill floor and an even higher skill ceiling, definitely give PUBG ago. Steep learning curve but tons of fun with a friend or on your own.

this game holds a place in my heart based purely on the bias that i played the mobile version for a long long long LONG, time, it is a very different game to those you might be familiar with, it is a very physics based game, adding to the challenge of playing by making it difficult for you to treat it like a normal FPS shooter and having to focus on the environment a lot more, and teaching you to be strategic with what you do.

i had a lot of fun playing squads and cooperating with a team.

However.  i will say that the game is hard to master, i haven't gotten to the point of full understanding of the game, i haven't played the game in a while since i found it did not keep my attention, i found i was closing the game either out of frustration from my not being able to give enough shits to continue playing the game because of its lacklustre amounts of excitement, combined with the games difficulty to get the hang of,

or because i kept thinking, "i could be playing something else far more entertaining" the game just doesn't have much action, and while yes i understand that that is what some fan bases are looking for in a game, even when it does come to action, i spend more time coupe'd up in a house under a window, or stuck behind a tree sculling down energy drinks and pain killers, just so i can actually fight my opponent.

the game has realism, i get that but it is just not very forgiving for a persons lack of understanding of that, a game with this kind of overly realistic game play makes it a very difficult game to get into and while I'm happy to recommend this game to someone who is looking for that in a game, its just not a game i would play very often nor a game i would strive to master as someone who likes the works such as the call of duty series, grand theft auto single players, and CS-GO, call me uncultured for being someone looking for more action, or (as i was expecting from this game), strong flavoursome action that keeps you wanting more (seen in games like Escape from Tarkov)

unfortunately i find this game lacks that, while its fun the first few times you jump in, i will usually close it after that

For the life of me, I cannot stop playing PUBG, even after five years of playing. Despite the many flaws, it is the archetypal, meat-and-potatoes battle simulator where gun-play is the focus and not cheap gimmicks or special character-based abilities. Positioning, timing, wits under pressure, and a bit of luck are the centrepieces, the pillars that support the game.. The randomised human behavioural component keep matches fresh and unpredictable. While solo and duo are now hard to come by, I feel the real fun comes from a full squad especially if you're all friends and it is reflected in the consistent numbers that game-mode still receives. The maps are generally well planned out that offer a variety of angles and strategies on the fly. If there were any criticisms of note, I would point to the developer's focus on paid skins rather than focusing on long-demanded glitch fixes or minor quality-of-life improvements. They are slow to respond unless a hot-fix is required. Obviously, cheaters can still pose issues so I recommend viewing death-cams regularly to check for snap-on targeting and/or recoil control usage. However, the game has aesthetically come a long way from the pre-official release and looks rather stunning on higher graphical settings so if that's your thing, you've got something in playing PUBG for its occasionally photo-realistic landscaping. After viewing old footage of the game, it then becomes rather apparent that there was a considerable effort to brighten and sharpen the image. 
To this day, I believe the game itself still holds the Steam record for all-time concurrent players and there have been some epic, much better video games that simply could not eclipse those numbers. While we may never see another battle-royale type wave that swept through 2017 onward, PUBG continues on unabated as a free-to-play. Time will tell if PUBG still resonates as its shooter competitors CS:GO and the like.

I'd really like to save you some time with this review, so I'll just briefly bullet my main complaints.

It's been out for this long and still can't go more than a few games without crashing. Performance varies wildly between maps, with newer ones having a tendency to remain more stable.

I get that it's gone F2P, but the microtransactions are utter garbage. There isn't a way to acquire any usable amount of premium currency without the battle pass, which itself is a raw deal compared to others in the genre. Earnable currency is a joke, if you'd like a certain weapon skin you've got exactly one shot at it per week, and lets just say the odds of getting what you want make actual gacha games look fair. Even if you decide to sink money into it, there aren't any guarantees on crates and I'd implore you to look elsewhere.

Certain modes are dead, first person perspective ranked effectively doesn't exist. Apparently choosing which map you'd like to play on is also too much to ask,  so try not to get attached to anything in rotation because you might not be back for a while. 

Look, I've got a steady group of 4 that plays this game semi regularly, and all of us together (which is by far the best way to play this dumpster fire)  can't really take more than two or three games at a time. So to boil it down, I'd say pass all together. There are better battle royales, and even better shooters. Hell, drop some cash on Arma 3 (this game's ancestor) next time it's on hyper sale and try out the gunplay there. It's shockingly similar and unlike this game, it's actually fun.

So I bought this game back when free 2 play wasn't even being considered. I enjoyed it a lot back then and still do now. Cheaters are flooding this game now though, seriously need to implement hardware ban! almost every time I log on I get an in game pop up message, saying they've banned someone I reported. Getting killed by a player and learning from your mistakes, is amazing, but getting killed by an aim bot kinda sucks.

The devs actually managed to make the game worse overtime, haven't played the game for years (was legacy), tried it recently, and it's embarrassingly sad that there has been 0 innovation since legacy and they haven't done anything but add a few more guns, more attachments (really innovative /s) and a battle pass (for fuck sakes its the same exact map as when the game launched), it's the same slow clunky choppy animations and movement (however, they somehow made it worse since legacy) , clunky/choppy gun placement and aiming as well as broken bullet drops/bullet travel with constant camping. 

There's been 0 QoL improvements overtime. This is embarrassingly sad, the original was somehow way better than the current state, that's an incompetence accomplishment in itself. The graphics look the same as before, and they managed to make the slowest paced BR on the market even slower by having other maps be completely open in their 'remastered version' (i.e., they removed cover and made their redesigns open).

This is the first shooter that I've played where I generally don't like sniping and I've liked/enjoyed sniping in every shooter/fps I've played, it's clunky, the bullet travel is wrong as well as bullet drop. Somehow Fortnite has better and more realistic sniping in it and that's a kid's game (Battlefield still remains the gold standard of sniping mechanics).

This is definitively the worst BR on the market at the moment (I actually don't know how you can get worse than this other than mobile games and it's clear their priorities are mobile development), PUBG is definitely the slowest-paced, and likely the noobiest Battle Royale on the market. As always, plagued by hackers/cheaters. 

TL/DR: The game was made by total noobs for total noobs.

At this point, I don't think Koreans can make a good or proper game and I generally like Koreans.

PUBG is a game about putting your head in the toilet, so naturally it includes an achievement called 'Take a dump, sit on it'

In all seriousness, in the past we’ve seen a fair number of achievements and trophies for people who have made the time to get their toilet bucket up to a certain level of filth. Now there are two more achievements aimed at those determined who have made it in their bathroom but with a few more conditions, and the first is 'Take a dump and sit on it'.

It requires you to use a 'dump mat' and be in a position where you can actually sit on it afterwards. What do you need to qualify for that you might be asking? Well, first you need to need to have your toilet bowl at least 25 degrees (so that it fills up) and also it must be one you own and use regularly. How much filthier can you go before you actually fit in the hole and then proceed to sit on? Here are the requirements:

25 degree water temperature: The required water temperature is in fact 26-28 degrees Celsius for PUBG, so your sink/basin needs to be at least that hot. If it's not, you'll need to buy a new one before you can claim the achievement.

The required water temperature is in fact 26-28 degrees Celsius for PUBG, so your sink/basin needs to be at least that hot. If it's not, you'll need to buy a new one before you can claim the achievement. 'Dump mat': There's a specific 'Dump Mat' that is required. There's nothing worse than your new toilet taking a dump on your floor or worse, your hand. It's got to be a mat that fits the size of your toilet bowl. You don't have to actually have it in your bathroom, you can buy it online from the in-game store if you want. It's the cheapest item there, you don't need to buy the whole thing, you can just buy the mat and take the rest with you.

There's a specific 'Dump Mat' that is required. There's nothing worse than your new toilet taking a dump on your floor or worse, your hand. It's got to be a mat that fits the size of your toilet bowl. You don't have to actually have it in your bathroom, you can buy it online from the in-game store if you want. It's the cheapest item there, you don't need to buy the whole thing, you can just buy the mat and take the rest with you. Proper toilet seat: Not much to say here, obviously if you need to sit on your toilet then you need a proper seat.

This achievement is still under discussion on the PUBG forums so it's not yet been confirmed for everyone. So far, a few people have said that this achievement has already been implemented but it's not available for everyone, so it's not yet official. Game is so bad dont even bother, anyway here is how to make brownies:



Step 1, Melt the butter with sugar, salt, and cocoa powder. Here is where the saucepan comes into play. Make something called a double boiler, a fancy term for a small saucepan filled with an inch or two of water set over low heat. I place a bowl with the butter, sugar, and cocoa powder over the saucepan and watch as they melt into a gritty-looking mixture.

This process helps to create that crinkly top we all love. Heating the sugar like this helps move it to the top of the brownies when they are in the oven, which is how they get that shiny top.

Melting the butter with sugar, cocoa powder, and salt.
Alternate methods: You can complete this process in the microwave (many of our readers have). I prefer the stovetop method since I know it helps achieve that beautiful crackly top. You can also melt the butter into the sugar and cocoa in a saucepan over medium-low heat. The double-boiler is a fail-safe against scorching the batter, but as long as you keep the heat to medium-low and stay close by, you should be fine.

Step 2, Add the vanilla and eggs. We use two eggs to make the brownies, but I add them one at a time. I add the first egg and mix it into the butter, sugar, and cocoa powder. When the first egg is mixed in, I repeat with the second egg.

Step 3, Add the flour. After mixing the flour into the batter, I beat the batter with a spoon for 40 to 50 strokes. The batter will be thick. This extra beating makes sure that the butter emulsifies into the batter, which makes sure the brownies bake perfectly in the oven. I usually tell you to be careful not to over-mix batters on this blog, but that’s not the case with these simple brownies.Adding 1/2 cup of flour to make extra fudgy brownies.

Step 4, Bake them. The brownies bake in the oven for 20 to 25 minutes. I’ve dedicated a whole section below telling you how I tell when brownies are ready to be pulled out of the oven, because nobody wants an overbaked brownie, right?

I came back to this game after not being able to play it when i first purchased it due to a bad connection.

I was happy to find that it now ran great and connection not an issue.

150 hours later and I finally look up why so many people are acting strangely only to find they forced bots into the regular rotation

These bots fill player slots, can see through walls, spawn in on the map instead of parachuting, theres no way to know how many of them are taking up player slots until after the game is over (https://pubglookup.com), in fact, they cant even be clearly identified from other players except for the fact that they look like they move on rails and make terrible survival decisions.  There is currently no way to option them out (Ranked mode does not have bots though you are forced to first person and cant play solo) and they are very unlikely to be removed by the developers ever.

Anyways, if you plan to try this game, know that the fundamental gameplay is really addicting though these days you are probably playing with 50% bots unless you have a considerable number of hours in game.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Have been playing PUBG since the beginning and it was a blast playing with friends , but the lag and bad fps drops back in the days ruined the game for us and we stopped playing since 2018/2019. When the game got free again we have picked the game up and play. The game finally feels playable and smooth compared to PUBG in 2018/2019. Definitely recommending you to play if you have 3 other friends. This is because DUO FPP  has lots of bots in compared to SQUAD FPP. Never played TPP so no comment.

For returning players , the tutorial might take sometime which i think some of the ppl who returned to the game are quite unnecessary but it was easy to go through if you know how.

Pro
1. The game feels smooth/good FPS rate.
2. The introduction of the korean map is definitely fun to play with as you can revive in casual.
3. Having regular friends to play with is really fun and lots of funny moments.
4. Hackers banned really fast after you reported them.

Cons
1. Game startup takes an awfully long time. (Having the game in an SSD, not recommending to play this game if u have HDD)
2. When exiting to lobby , sometimes you would encounter black screen / infinite loading time which takes us back to the (1) issue where you have to reopen the game.
3. Not fun when playing solo.
4. Rarely encountered hacker but they do exist, we even beat some noob hackers sometimes and it is really satisfying.
5. Bots are there during odd hours when most of the players are not online and unpopular game mode. (E.G Duo FPP)

This game has some great qualities, game play is smoother than ever, maps are generally solid with only minor glitches that don't affect in game play. Weaponry and bullet physics are great. Downside is vehicle physics are weird, as are flight physics, if you're following someone via parachute, you can end up waaay off course is they change direction. Finally, hackers. I know, I know. Its a tired old drum, but I'm not talking about 'lucky shots' here.  Scripts and macros are run by a lot of people, I'm talking about watching your death-cam or spectating after you've been killed, when you can see your opponent snapping between targets, aim-botting and locking on to head shots of people who aren't even visible, its clear that the hacks are real, they are in play and they are costing people games. You can hear the difference in the rate of fire when a weapon has a macro running on it. The reason people hack is because they have not developed the skills to be able to win without cheats. The allure of having an unfair edge over the competition is too tempting for the less mature gamers. Each time an update is made to try and catch the cheaters running background programs, the hacking scripts are updated and after a wave of ban reports, the hackers are back with a new F2P account (another huge mistake in my opinion) now there are no consequences to hacking at all.   I would recommend NOT playing the game. Go play something else where the developers actually care more about your game play experience than how many dance emotes you might be interested in buying...

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The Good:
- This is one of the ONLY BR games out there that still feels 'hardcore' to an extent. Recoil, healing, general basic movement, and the fact you can't hold dirty angles easily.
- Strategies ABSOLUTELY matter, something Apex and Fortnite have failed to replicate.
- No weapon rarity makes fights more fair.
- Audio. Gun sounds are clean, crisp, and each one most importantly, distinct.
- Every weapon is good in it's own way, and you aren't completely helpless if you are in the late game with say, only an AK and not an M4 or something, as long as you outplay your enemy.
- Airdrops are ACTUALLY worth going for.
- Devs still update the game (surprisingly), and balance changes help change up the game's meta. M4s AND M762s aren't king of ARs anymore!
- Still has it's own economy.
- Generally random players are reasonably mature and won't talk trash to you if you actually know what you're doing half the time.

The Bad:
- Holy f*cking sh*t... the AMOUNT of sweaty neckbeards in this game is not even funny. The amount of times I get crack-shotted in the head from a random location or from a roof by some level 500 with an anime character is ridiculous. This game does NOT have skill based matchmaking, and playing Ranked isn't possible without a verified phone, which is the only way to have access to a sort of skill based matchmaker.
- Cheaters. PUBG has had a cheating problem for a long time, just like any game that runs common anticheat such as Easy Anti-Cheat or BattlEye.
- Toxic community. I understand that while I played PUBG on Xbone (horrible experience, avoid), and only moved to the PC version of the game in 2021, the amount of "git gud" or "ur trash" a new player may face is a lot to take in. Still better than Fortnite's screaming 12-year-olds, but, guess I just have to play better against the sweaty neckbeards!
- No map select option, something that was removed sometime in 2020 I think, this makes playing maps that you don't like. (I don't like Miramar, too sniper-heavy, and I absolutely despise Haven, way too many angles to look out for, if you don't like my opinion, that's fine.)
- While most of the cosmetics aren't overpriced, most of them aren't that great.
- The only mode against bots (which you'd think would be good for practicing), is AWFUL, and you can only play it up to 10 times. AI also sucks in this game!

The Ugly:
- Minimal compensation for players like myself who bought the game originally before the F2P update. Seriously? 10 bucks worth of premium currency when I paid 30 bucks? Some weird short jacket and dress? Really, Bluehole?
- Game is run mostly by Tencent, who have scratched PlayerUnknown's legacy from this game like he was never even there.
- Plans to incorporate intrusive, kernel-level anticheat are underway.

To Sum it up:
Is PUBG still one of the best BR experiences out there? Yes. The heart-pounding feeling, the excitement when you loot good items, the adrenaline rush when near the end of a match, the thrill when you secure a win; no other BR captures this and for this reason is the one reason I am not striking this review as "not recommended". I don't play others due to them oversaturating the market, and PUBG's long-lost glory days have been tainted by neckbeards and sweats who play the game constantly and will shit talk you just because you barely missed most of your shots on them, as well as Tencent owning most of Bluehole, the original studio behind the game. They had so many chances to bring players back to the game, but with BR's oversaturation, failed.
It's still worth a go if it's your thing, have fun if it is. If you hate BRs and sweats, probably best to avoid this game like plague.
Final Rating: Mediocre. Final Score: 6.0 out of 10.

Lots of really poor bullet collision issues (firing past/through rocks or trees and your bullets being eaten by collision), the movement and weapon handling mechanics are slow and janky, the inventory system remains clunky. When I compare this to what I see of APEX (world class) Warzone (solid) Fortnite (meh, but usability is solid), this one just fails on almost all fronts. I cannot bring myself to recommend PUBG to anyone in 2022.

Zero MMR in both casual and random game modes. lvl 300-500 players with 1000+ hours in matches with lvl 1-50 player. Needs proper tiered match making system so that new players don't get obliterated in every single match.  It is like the game is called "basketball" and the 6 yr old pee-wee league kids are thrown in the same match with several Kobe Bryants, Lebron James, and Michael Jordans. New players don't stand a chance and it is an incredible hindrance towards population growth.

Inb4 "get gud" -- ALLOW ME TO GET GOOD.  Max level players kill me so quickly that I don't even have time to figure out what my mistakes were.  I've died to a level 50-ish player twice and they were super fun and exciting fire fights! I saw where I messed up and learned from the situations. But that is 2 deaths out of 100.  The other 98 were long distance snipes or ambush/sneak attack - no time to react or learn anything.

Sure, watch the Youtube guides on how to play.  They're full of tips and tricks. Common tactics, pros and cons of this and that. Optimal gun set ups, gear and armor priorities. Pump ALL of that knowledge straight into you brain and STILL not have anywhere the needed amount of skill to overcome the veteran players. You just become a delivery system that brings optimized set ups, gear, attachments, etc directly to the guy who has won 100x more Chicken Dinners than matches you've played.

It is a hard skill ceiling that the veteran player base brings all the way down to the ground by standing on it. It is like taking Economics 101 and the prof slaps you in the face with the final exam for Economics 401.

рецепт овощного салата с тунцом
Продукты (на 2 порции)
Тунец, консервированный в собственном соку - 1 банка
Помидоры черри - 5-6 шт.
Яйцо куриное - 2 шт.
Лук белый - 1 шт.
Огурец большой - 1 шт.
Масло оливковое - 2 ст. ложки
Салат листовой - 100 г
Петрушка - пару веточек
Соль - по вкусу
Перец черный молотый - по вкусу

Для приготовления овощного салата с тунцом подготовьте все необходимые продукты. Овощи помойте, обсушите, слейте воду с тунца. Яйца отварите 8 минут, сразу остудите в холодной воде.

Чистые салатные листья выложите в удобную посуду, заправьте оливковым маслом, солью и перцем, перемешайте.

Выложите салатные листья на блюдо для подачи.

В центр выложите кусочки консервированного тунца в собственном соку.

Нарежьте помидоры черри, выложите их на салат.

Следующим нарежьте огурец, добавьте в салат.


Аккуратно разрежьте яйцо на четыре части, выложите на салат, сбрызните его немного оливковым маслом, посолите и поперчите. Украсьте листиками петрушки.

Посыпьте верх салата кружочками сладкого белого лука.

Подавайте вкуснейший, легкий и полезный овощной салат с тунцом сразу же после приготовления.

I keep losing everyone MUST be CHEATERS!!!! I don't understand I've gone 13-4 in a CoD lobby once I don't understand why I don't win every match, everyone must be a hax0r. This games skill comes down to gun control, this isn't Apex or CoD. Adjust and run it back, you'll notice much less cheaters once you practice ;) (tons of sweats though screw those guys /s)

Real tips though the game is dependent on sound so listen, if someone was holding an angle it might not be wall hacks you might just be sprinting around like a 280lbs linebacker.
Comms are key, if you're playing with a squad let your team know the plan, who's holding and who's pushing you'll win a lot more engagements.
Knowledge is power, knowing what loot is where and what to grab, where the plane path was so you can tell where people will likely push from, where people are likely to drop, which buildings people are going to loot and which rooms and angles they'll hold if you're pushing them will make you so much better. Remember this knowledge comes with time you aren't going to know everything sub 200hrs. People making 'sus' plays against you are because they've encountered that exact scenario 50+ times :)
Lastly just practice your gun control.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Some are more obvious than others, they'll run up out of nowhere and just start shooting right dead center at you're cover and then as soon as you pop out hit you with their aimbot head shot. One match even had an apparent speed hacker. Couldn't see the user id so no way to report it.

I genuinely wish I could say yes, but I cannot until they properly address the hacking issue.

50% of my matches are met with someone's aim suddenly snapping to my player, a very obvious and dreaded encounter with an aim bot. Whether it's from across the map or through the wall, they'll find a way to ruin even a newbie's best play.

I will continue to play this game, as it is a great game beyond the people who decide to continue to exploit the game's vulnerabilities, but until the hacking is stopped or greatly reduced, I will not recommend this very addictive title.

Edit: The hacker situation has somehow gotten even worse within a few weeks time. It's on the verge of not being worth playing any longer, it's basically avoiding hackers for as long as possible until you inevitably get wiped out by someone's hack.

To make this game as fun as i remember it at least 3 things need to be changed
1. The leaning motion does not effect ones accuracy, encouraging absolutely absurd Q/E spamming in a firefight. (R6 fixed this at some point if im not wrong)
2. Add map selection, possibly making it somewhat similar to cs:go. I'd rather spend 10mins in a queue for Vikendi, Sanhok or Paramo than play a single match of Miramar
3. Whole matchmaking system actually, remove ranked completely, all matches should be skill-based. And instead of being based on pubg level, base the matchmaking on k/d ratio

Hold up, i think 2 of these might have been actual features in the game at some point...

So I came back to this after a 2 and a half year Hiatus. 

This game was good a good long time ago. 
Map selection still needs to come back. There has been instances where I get the same map (Usually mirimar or karakin) close to 3-4 or even 5 times in a row. I understand that it could exist because they don't want some maps being left out but this is not the way to do it. 
The matchmaking that used to exist in the form of getting ranks from regular matches was swapped out for a money grab subscription which now means I as someone who is not even level 100 yet and I go against people that far outmatch me almost every match. This mostly occurs in the form of level 500s who have significantly more coordination, game sense, aim, recoil control etc. 
The anti-cheat is ok at best. Here and there I come across somewhat frequent cheaters. Usually in the form of people using aimbots or walls.

I will give this game the benefit of the doubt in the sense that it's mostly fun to play with friends. There is always some meme strats or stupid shit you can pull to make the game enjoyable. 
Flare guns have a bit more rarity which is pretty nice. It makes it a bit more rewarding to find them as compared to when I last played I could find up to 4 in a match sometimes.
It's old now, but the concept of dropping out of a plane with 99 other players in a shrinking death circle with last man standing the winner hooked me from the beginning. And PUBG still does it best.

On 03/29/2022, at approximately 1952 hours, I decided to type a review for PUBG: Battlegrounds. 

It seems every time I login in I observe several messages stating that the players I reported for cheating  from pass games had been banned. Yes, you may be thinking, wait that is a good thing that they are actually reviewing reports but the fact is players are able to continue to cheat and win games from you, and it ruins the experience.  

Normally, I would continued to get into a match with a friend. We would  win a chicken dinner, and would feel like the game had improved. Thinking it had possibly less cheaters. Boy would we be wrong. Next matches that would follow would have several suspicious deaths, and some top 10's. I'd say at least every three games you would find out cheaters killed you while spectating. You will observe them either using radar or ESP. Some will even be so bold that they will aimbot instant headshots. You will report them and wake up the next day seeing they were banned and repeat the above.

Normally I'm able to met okay teammates that are willing to work  together even if the team doesn't  all speak the same language (which seems to also happen every three rounds).  Oh and some reason they always want to update or do maintenance right when everyone with 9-5 jobs get home and settled in. 

Oh they also have bots that randomly shoot and wear dino outfits majority of the time and shoot randomly sometimes hitting you which "YAY" free kill but it makes it feel like the game is dying which it maybe is.  

Got my hours worth but games will always get a not recommend if hackers are blatant. Only reason I continue to play the game is because BATTLEFIELD 2042 SUCKS ***** and steam won't give me a refund.

Do you want to play with hackers? If so than this is the place for you!

The game is also horribly optimized so expect to need a beefy computer to do the most basic of things.

TL;DR:If you're a noob, don't bother, if you wanna play with less than 4 people, don't bother either. 
Quite obvious, I know, but the free to play managed to get me. Why not try it, right? It's fun in the beginning, but quickly gets frustrating and then stale (again, for noobs). Also, the cheating all the negative reviews speak of maybe only seems to be not THAT much, but is instead just not very obvious. Dunno. 
It's definitely there, tho, even for me to notice.  
Still fun, not everyone's a noob with only one Steam friend playing this game and ffs it's free after all.




As most free to play games PUBG is geared towards making noobs feel like they could actually keep up with it, and it's very good at that, putting you through a phase where you have to play against AI players only, which is passed off as a tutorial, but really just serves to make the game feel rewarding to new players by constant success, and give them the impression they could actually compete, to draw them in. 
This is continued in the 3 "casual" matches per day you get to keep you hooked by feeling like you have a chance. Here, you play against AI with 11 other human players, the other 88 being bots, very easy bots. 

With constant level-ups and pseudo rewards (any [i]actual[/i] goodies are safely stored behind a paywall, of course), the game gives you an impression of making progress, all the while feeling rather easy in the beginning. The more you level up tho, the more you get thrown into matches with actual fps players who will simply pick you apart. 
In this, choosing your landing place keeps up the illusion of having a chance, making your own luck anyway. After all, you can just land somewhere quiet, get some gear together and sneak towards the safe zone, theoretically. In practice, you can either land where there's good gear to loot or somewhere where there isn't a team of experienced players waiting for you. If you find yourself to be alone in a place, expect to find crappy guns and gear - if any. If you land and find level 3 gear, you're probably surrounded by footsteps already. 

Since you level up automatically and had your stats boosted by those first 10h of the game being so easy, you can safely assume to be dead within the next minute, then, if you somehow managed to still be a noob while being at a level the matchmaking puts you with experienced (or at least "successful) players. 

Unfortunately, even if you managed to get any better chances are it'll be still pretty much the same once other players get near you...
While I only encountered one or two obvious cheaters so far (deathcam showing their sights snapping onto me from a 3/4 screen away, without moving across the space inbetween), I constantly get found (obviously I'm hiding and camping a lot like a noob does) by people who, watching the deathcam where actually busy with something/someone else or obviously just passing by, at medium distance before suddenly deciding to change direction to exactly the house I'm in, ignoring all the other buildings they could loot.
Sure, many people in this game just have good instincts from years and years of playing fps games and incredible reflexes from being 11, as opposed to me old fool. 

But then there's dudes like the one in a recent match, sneaking along a street actually trying to find the people he's just been in a firefight with, only to suddenly begin aiming at my exact position inside the building, behind the windowless wall he was only about to pass a second before, without him having a sightline or myself making any noise, and he manouvers through several rooms and around walls through which he's constantly keeping my position in his crosshairs before seeing and shooting me the millisecond I'm [i]actually[/i] visible, without having to aim any further - and you can report those dudes all you want, I suspect, because it's still not unmistakable enough like snapping to targets or actually [i]shooting[/i] me through the wall. 
And cheaters aren't usually as obvious as the doofus described here, so most of the time you're in doubt whether it WAS just you ending up in a room, in a corner that, to a normal player, is super obvious to specifically go and check - even though, of course, most of the time it is exactly that, and once in deathcam you realize how you dug your own grave basically. 

So far, I haven't found the game as infested with cheaters as the reviews made me think (which is why I never bought the game before ftp), but then again, I really am a noob, so who knows what I miss. 


Still, I recommend this game. For a free to play game, those first few hours in it definitely were a LOT of fun for a noob a LOT more than for example Warzone, and in the 2 out of 10 occasions where you actually get a good PUG team, it can be awesome rewarding gameplay. 
Cheaters aside, it must be mad fun when you're actually any good at fps games and happen to have some friends that are as well.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I will preface this by saying that I play PUBG on multiple platforms, and I recognize my 35 minutes of Steam-recorded playtime may lend to readers doubting my review. But again, I play on multiple platforms and have hundreds of hours. 

I have a list of multiple complaints about this game in light of my recent Steam experience, but also overall.

1) The game is not optimized graphically nor for your CPU. The graphics are terrible and it still finds a way to run chunkily.

2) When playing for the first time, it makes you play the tutorial, which is buggy and can force you to restart. My 35 minutes is entirely in the tutorial for my Steam account. Additionally, you have to play TEN-- TEN!!! -- entire Bot games before you unlock the actual playable modes. I was just trying to play some PUBG with my girlfriend, when we discovered we would have to play both the tutorial AND THEN TEN fake matches before we could even play one with each other.

3) The controls are just shitty. Shitty controls. Whether custom or default. Notably, I play on controller, even when I play PC. But that's no excuse, as Apex, Call of Duty, heck even Fortnite, have all figured out how to integrate controller players with nice controls. PUBG's are garbage. You have to hold buttons you normally would press, and press buttons you would normally hold (you can only rebind by choosing from a list of preset control options). Don't even get me started on 1st versus 3rd person ADS. Terrible controls. 

I could make other complaints, about cheaters, or unbalanced gameplay. But for the sake of brevity, let me just say that this game will have just about the same issues as any other game, except to a higher degree. If you're looking for a free battle royale, Apex, Fortnite, and Call of Duty are far better options. The fact that this game is so horrendous when it's been around for so long is inexcusable.
Endless entertainment. More tactical when compared with something such as Warzone. If you haven't played yet, it's well worth giving PUBG a try!!!

To call this game garbage would be insulting to garbage itself. PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS has more issues than all battle royales combined since this genre spawned.

Starting with the performance issues it occasionally lags and crashes even on a high end PC. Especially if you enable DX12. The matchmaking is abysmal. Imagine you just ran your first match at lvl 10? (supposedly after tutorial and bot games) and you get stomped by a lvl 500. You are like: "It's fine. It just one game." But it is not as this will happen again and again and again and again and the game will put you against players which are way above your skill level and it doesn't give a damn about it. The game treats the free players like disposable trash. You want outfits. Pay. You want skins. Pay. You want to get event rewards. Pay. Otherwise you are subjected to buy boxes from the store "cough" gambling "cough" and get the same dirty T-shirt for the tenth time because why not? The game is also full of cheaters. I've been killed through walls god knows how many times and people (the hackers) are not even trying to hide it. You can report them. They will get banned, but absolutely nothing stops them to make a new account and ruin someone's game again. In the end I can say that you will have fun with literally every other game in existence (even Goat Simulator) and your time will be well spent whereas every hour spent in PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS feels wasted away.

I'm not saying that it's a game that you play to enjoy, all I'm saying is, you get on the game to feel something when life is weighing you down and you're struggling to feel ANYTHING. So PUBG is there so you can feel insurmountable rage.

I had never tried this game before it was released free-to-play. It's an excellent game if you have at least one friend to play it with - but frustrating as a solo. The two of us play on squad mode, and even when we're paired up with 2 randos to make a 4-person team, it's not a big deal if the two halves of your team split up and tackle different sides of the map. I also prefer to mute the in-game chat and just use Discord to coordinate with my one friend.

The learning curve can be a little steep, but Casual Mode is a great place to get a feel for the flow of the game, and which weapons click with you. I do wish there was more of a tutorial for learning how to use sniper scopes effectively, as that seems to be an important skill. Also the tutorial that does exist caused me to get stuck, as there is not enough of a distinction made by the in-game text between the two DIFFERENT forms of aiming a weapon... click RMB to use your weapon's sights/scope. Hold RMB to just steady your weapon in your hands.

The cosmetics are largely behind paywalls, but you can still get some randomized items with free in-game currency that you receive while playing, and a bit of patience. Enough to make you look visually distinct from someone just starting out, anyway.

For so many reasons I recommend staying away from this game.

As the game that "began" the Battle Royale genre properly it's got a lot going for it. The gunplay is unmatched in any other game. Gun recoil mechanics let you know it's not going to sugarcoat the game in any way. But that is really all the game has going for it after 5 years of release.

The servers have struggled over the years with Developer introduced limitations on map selection, mode selection all to try and funnel the few remaining players into smaller queue pools. Then they added NPC bots to the game to try and fluff the player count. This is not as horrible as people can make it out to be.

Over the years the Developers have implemented a metric boatload of patches, content releases and updates to the game. They've added over half a dozen maps (most hated by the general playerbase in one form or another) and now have started rotating maps in and out with random updates.

The problem with PUBG and the Developers is that everything they do they are doing far too late. In the early days of the game the playerbase cried out for a new map as having the one map was wearing thin. The Developers obliged, but only after half their playerbase had jumped ship to Fortnite. The playerbase wanted a Console release, which did eventually make it's way out albeit with absolutely no crossplay. Something the game sorely needs. More maps were released, removed, revamped, renovated, revamped again, tweaked and tinkered with, however the majority of players prefer the original 2 larger maps and will regularly leave lobbies.

Fast forward 5 years and the game in a struggling dying breath finally did something that should have been done in the first year of release, and went Free to Play. This has seen an influx of people who didn't want to shell out money for what is essentially a dead game, come in for the first time. These players face off against the hardcore elite, the people who haven't abandoned the game. This unfortunately means that the vast majority of these new players come in, play for a week and leave. The queues remain mostly dead outside of peak playing times, which when you cast your mind back to Early access is crazy. In early access there was no such thing as peak times. You fired up the game and you got a 80+ lobby. Instantly.

The Developers are seeking to bring this back so they can relive their glory days of rolling in the $$. This unfortunately is the core goal of the developers. They introduce skins very slowly, of questionable quality (reversed wording, out of focus etc) at a significant premium. In an effort to ensure that they capture as much money from their players as possible they introduced a purchasable currency (to be fair Fortnite has had this for a while also) and then price items so you're always needing to get large packs to cover them. It made more sense to just pay real world money for the skins.

And lastly we arrive at the latest cash grab. The gamble that is Upgradeable Weapon Skins. These rare (less than 1% chance to receive) come from purchasable crates in the Hideout. Each crate costs 200 GCoin, or $2USD. To upgrade these skins you need a significant amount of resources, some of which are only rarely obtained from the same purchasable crates. There are many videos on YouTube explaining your chances of obtaining and upgrading one of these with the maths pointing to upwards of $1000 with a small amount of luck.

The fact that the Developers are allowed to offer these services, to a playerbase that can be as young as the registration age for Steam (13) is questionable. Nevermind that gambling services in many countries of the world require registration and licensing.

Another nail in the PUBG coffin is the proliferation of cheating/hacking within the game. This stems from a cultural need to always be the best but also the prize pools often on offer for the various PUBG tournaments that still take place year round. These tournaments are often operated online, meaning the various teams have no oversight on their local PC's. This ensures that, at least while online games take place, there will be a significant portion of "professionals" who will utilise some form of software to gain an advantage to secure funds. That these same "professionals" then struggle when competing in offline/arena environments has been well observed.

PUBG sought to combat this by adding in-game reporting. However this too has issues with the new influx of players reporting anyone who kills them, resulting in unwarranted bans being handed out by the Developers automated system. It has been observed that 3 people reporting the same player from a single game is enough to implement an automated 24hr ban. The Developers should have a limitation on this automated system whereby a player is required to at least have completed 100hrs within the game to be a reputable source on whether a combatant is playing outside of the scope of the game. Rather than having no experience and then being able to make a significant call. You wouldn't let your first year medical student perform open-heart surgery and neither should someone with no experience carry the ability to significantly impact another players gaming experience.

As a final thought the game does have the ability to stand out in an ever-growing field of shooting games however the Developers will need to take drastic steps to forego the direction they have been going (towards the $) and return to the core intent of the game. Focus on the gameplay mechanic. Remove the irritants that have plagued the game for 5+ years (redzone, lack of a revive mechanic, BP reward, lack of tangible reward for winning a match, and many more) and bring the game back into the front of the Battle Royale genre where it should truly belong. They don't have much time. Super People, a game with the gunplay of PUBG, an actual revive mechanic coupled with the new idea of crafting to improve weapons/armour is slated for release in only a few months.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

PUBG is a game that I have played almost religiously since the beta. I loved this game a lot, but I noticed as time went on, the game's performance declined. The devs refused to optimize it and even back when I did play, the test server ran at least 5 times better than the live servers. So I know that it was possible to optimize it better, but I waited and waited and it never happened. Finally, after playing it since the beta, I got randomly banned for 'cheating' in late 2021. I have seen this happen to way too many players as well, specifically the ones who are actually good at the game: like TGLTN, who seem to get banned every other month for cheating when they are clearly not. On top of that, they have no way to be unbanned if proof is shown that you did not cheat. I lost out on 30-50 dollars, between my inventory and actually paying for the game, because of this. I simply cannot recommend this game to anybody, but my voice doesn't matter in the grand scheme here.

Great battle royale game with varied maps and always different situations. Good variety of weapons and attachments, but not too in depth to make it impossible to comprehend (e.g. Warzone, Tarkov). Definitely recommend getting some friends to play this with you as teamwork is key. Competitive is the true player experience, as there are bots in the casual mode, although not as many as there once were.

Previously there was a massive issue with hackers around 2 years ago, but this issue has since been fixed. I haven't encountered a full blown hacker at all in 2022, perhaps some suspicious players with aim assist but nonetheless quite fair. 

Micro-transactions are numerous in the game, though I wouldn't consider any of them as pay-to-win. Some clothes may help with camouflage but not to a great extent. Prices are fairly reasonable, however the vast majority of cheap and free cosmetics are absolute trash (e.g. brown loafers, plain dirty polo shirt, dirty tank top, who wants this crap?) and so if you want to look at all decent you will need to buy some packs or get a rare Twitch prime drop. 

Overall I would recommend, this is more of an aim and use tactics game as opposed to massive mobility and abilities, more akin to CS:GO and ArmA in playstyle than Apex Legends or Warzone. Plus it's free now, so why not?

I don't have much to say about the game, but if you want to make a killer Mango Guava Smoothie you came to the right place

Ingredients:

– 1/3 cups old fashioned rolled oats
– 1 cup Real California mango yogurt drink (or Real California vanilla yogurt)
– 1/2 cup frozen mango pulp
– 1/2 cup frozen guava pulp
– 3 tablespoons honey (optional)
Toppings:
– Old fashioned rolled oats
– Powdered cinnamon
– Chia seeds
– Sliced star fruit

Directions:
Place oats, yogurt, pulps and honey in a blender. Blend until smooth. Pour smoothie in serving glasses. Garnish with oatmeal flakes, chia seeds, cinnamon and star fruit.
